item.body:
New York is one of the world’s most exciting and vibrant cities. Millions of people from around the United States and around the world fly in and out of New York every year.

Flying out of New York

New York is served by three main airports that handle international commercial flights. They are:

  • JFK - John F. Kennedy International Airport. JFK has been New York’s main international airport for many years and handles over 25 million passengers annually. It is located in Queens, at the southern tip of the Van Wyck Expressway. It also handles a number of domestic flights.
  • LGA - LaGuardia Airport. Although LGA is primarily a domestic airport, some airlines, like major carrier, Continental Airlines, also use it as an international hub. Close to 13.5 million people passed through LaGuardia last year.
  • EWR - Newark International Airport. Newark Airport is situated in Newark, New Jersey and is used by both domestic and international carriers. Its distance from the centre of New York may dissuade travellers short on time but the facilities here are more modern and it is less crowded than both JFK and LGA.

Flying into Hong Kong

The tiny island of Hong Kong really only has space for a single airport and the honour goes to HKG - Chek Lap Kok Hong Kong International Airport

Opened in 1998, HKG is now the world’s eighth-busiest airport by passenger numbers – over 70.5 million people walked through its gates last year. The airport is located on its own man-made island just off Hong Kong island itself.

Why Fly First Class?

Flying first class is an experience unto itself, and the experience begins even before you board your flight.

Exclusive check-in counters make the start of the airport experience a pleasure. The process is a breeze, handled by your airlines’ best and most adept ground crew. Depending on the airport, you will have access to a premium lounge for all first class and business class passengers or those from your airline only.

The opulent surrounds are enhanced by premium food and drink as you wait to board. First class and business class passengers get priority boarding which makes the transition onto the plane simple and unhurried. On board, the excellent service continues.

Food and drink for first class and business class passengers are a cut above those served to others. The seating is wider and more comfortable. Entertainment options can be better enjoyed because the screens are larger and the headphones are superior.

Rest and relax on seats that recline and lie flat. A direct flight from New York to Hong Kong takes 16 hours – a premium seat will get you there rested, looking good and feeling better than you have in a long time.

Why buy tickets with I Fly First Class?

I Fly First Class gives you the best deals on the best seats on every flight. We find seats for you at short notice and even those on flights which a travel agent will tell you is already booked out.

Cheap luxury tickets on your schedule – that’s the I Fly First Class promise.

How to find tickets on I Fly First Class

I Fly First Class gives you three convenient options to get the seat of your dreams on the flight of your choice:

  • You can call our toll-free number 1-800-385-1359 in the U.S.A. and speak to us directly.
  • You may email us your requirements at info@FlyFirst.com and have a travel specialist contact you.
  • Visit www.iflyfirstclass.com to fill in the online form and we will contact you with all the options at your disposal.

What are you waiting for? Your premium airborne experience awaits!

item.body:
Flying out of New York

Three international airports serve New York.

JFK - John F. Kennedy International Airport

JFK is virtually synonymous with international travel to New York. It has been the city’s main international airport for many years and handles over 25 million passengers annually. Located in Queens, at the southern tip of the Van Wyck Expressway, it is also used for a small number of domestic flights.

LGA - LaGuardia Airport

LGA is New York’s primary domestic airport but is now used by some airlines like Continental as an international hub. Almost 13.5 million people passed through LaGuardia’s gates in 2016.

EWR - Newark International Airport

Situated in Newark, New Jersey, Newark Airport is used by both domestic and international carriers. Its facilities are more modern and it is less crowded than JFK and LGA. However, it is slightly further from the city centre than they are.

Flying into Tokyo

Tokyo is served by two international airports – Haneda and Narita. Different airlines use one or the other and while the facilities at each are virtually identical, the most important factor in a traveller’s choice of airports is often the distance of each from Tokyo.

HND - Haneda Airport

Haneda Airport is just 15 km from the centre of the city, making it the most convenient stop for anyone short on time. By rail, the commute from Haneda to Tokyo takes just half an hour.

NRT - Narita Airport

Narita Airport is situated not in Tokyo, but in Chiba prefecture, 65 km away. A train ride to Tokyo from Narita will take over an hour.

In first and business class, you will have access to more personal space all around – larger legroom, wider armrests, even an individual cabin on certain airlines. Premium class seats recline completely flat so you will arrive in Tokyo rested and ready for work, play or both.

The food, drink and entertainment options are a world part, too. Good wine, chef-prepared meals, large personal screens and high-quality headphones add to the pleasurable experience.

I Fly First Class specialises in finding the cheapest first class and business class air tickets for our clients. We don’t just find regular seats; we have the connections within the industry to procure seats on sold-out flights at short notice.

item.body:
Flying out of New York

You have a choice of three international airports when flying from New York.

JFK - John F. Kennedy International Airport

JFK has been the city’s main international airport for a quarter of a century and handles over 25 million passengers every year. Located at the southern tip of the Van Wyck Expressway in the district of Queens, it is also a minor hub for domestic flights.

LGA - LaGuardia Airport

LGA is primarily a domestic airport but is also used by airlines like Continental as an international stop. Handling over 13 million passengers in 2016, LaGuardia is a popular choice for those seeking a less busy alternative to JFK.

EWR - Newark International Airport

Newark, New Jersey’s Newark Airport is both a domestic and an international airport. Newer than both JFK and LGA, its facilities are more modern and it is less crowded than either. However, its distance from New York City may deter some passengers on tight schedules.

Flying into Seoul

There are two airports to choose from.

ICN - Incheon International Airport

Rated as the world’s best airport by Airports Council International every year since 2005, Incheon Airport features a golf course, casino, spa, ice skating rink and private sleeping rooms. It is also consistently ranked the world’s cleanest airport, the best transit airport and the airport with the best shopping mall.

Almost all international flights arrive at Incheon, which is 48 km from Seoul.

GMP - Gimpo International Airport

Located just 15 km west of Seoul, Gimpo is much closer to the city than Incheon. However, it is mainly a domestic airport and only serves international flights between South Korean and Japan, Taiwan and China.

It takes at least 14 hours 20 minutes to fly from NY to Seoul. If you have sat in an economy class seat before, you can imagine what an ordeal it will be to be stuck in such a small space for such a long stretch.

Haneda and Narita Airports are the two international airports serving Tokyo. While the facilities at each are virtually identical, the most important factor in a traveller’s choice of airports is often the distance of each from Tokyo.

Delta Airlines is the only airline that operates out of Los Angeles only to Haneda. United, Singapore Airlines and Japan Airways fly exclusively between Los Angeles and Narita. All Nippon Airways and American Airlines fly to both Haneda and Narita.

HND - Haneda Airport

Haneda Airport is just 15 km from the centre of Tokyo city. It is the better option for travellers short on time. The commute from Haneda to Tokyo takes just half an hour by the efficient rail network.

NRT - Narita Airport

The Sydney to Hong Kong direct route is operated by the respective native carriers of Hong Kong and Australia, Cathay Pacific and Qantas.

Flying into Hong Kong

Hong Kong’s international air passenger needs are served by the modern, expansive and award-winning Chek Lap Kok Hong Kong International Airport (HKG). It is spread across an artificial island constructed from reclaimed land just off Hong Kong.

71 million passengers used Chek Lap Kok in 2016 for arrivals, departures and transits, making it the world’s eighth-busiest airport by passenger numbers. The HKIA Airport Express links the airport to Hong Kong’s CBD. Coaches, taxis and limousines make public transport to and from the airport a breeze.

The Sydney to Tokyo route is operated by Australia’s native carrier, Qantas and by the Japanese Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines.

All Nippon Airways and Qantas fly exclusively to Haneda Airport while Japan Airlines flies only to Narita.

Flying into Tokyo

Flights from Sydney land in one of the two international airports serving Tokyo, Haneda and Narita. The airports themselves are both excellent – modern, clean and extremely orderly. Most passengers choose to land at one or the other because of the relative proximity to Tokyo and other regional destinations.

HND - Haneda Airport

At just 15 km from the centre of the city, Haneda Airport is the most convenient airport option if you have hotel reservations within the city. Once you clear the efficient arrival process at Haneda, a rain commute will take just 15 minutes before you are in the centre of one of the world’s most modern and exciting cities.

NRT - Narita Airport

Despite being regarded as a ‘Tokyo Airport’, Narita Airport is actually situated outside it, 65 km away in Chiba prefecture. A train ride to Tokyo from Narita takes approximately one hour.

Whether you land at Haneda or Narita, a direct flight from Sydney to Tokyo is over 9 hours and 35 minutes long. How you look and feel at the end of the arduous journey depends a great deal on whether you travelled by coach, or decided to invest in a first class or business class seat.

Flying into Hong Kong

All of Hong Kong’s international air passenger traffic is handled by the Chek Lap Kok Hong Kong International Airport (HKG). Flights from Chicago’s O’hare International Airport arrive here.

Chek Lap Kok is just behind O’Hare in terms of passenger numbers – 71 million in 2016 – making it the world’s eighth-busiest airport. The airport has been built on an artificial island just off Hong Kong. The HKIA Airport Express links directly to Hong Kong’s CBD. Flying out of Hong Kong

Despite the large volume of air traffic, both passenger and cargo that originates at, departs from and transits through Hong Kong, its needs are served by a single international airport. The challenge is taken up by the impressive Hong Kong International Airport (HKG), known locally as Chek Lap Kok.

Sitting on its own island just off the coast of Hong Kong, Chek Lap Kok saw 71 million passengers walk through its halls in 2016, making it the world’s eighth-busiest airport by passenger numbers.

It is conveniently connected to the rest of the territory by coaches, taxis and limousines. Flights to Tokyo from HKIA may land at either Haneda or Narita Airports.

Flying into Tokyo

Tokyo is served by two international airports – Haneda and Narita. The facilities at both are excellent in being modern and clean in the way for which Japan is famous. The most important factor in a traveller’s choice of airports is often the distance of each from Tokyo:

  • HND - Haneda Airport. Haneda Airport is just 15 km from the centre of the city, making it the most convenient stop for anyone short on time. By rail, the commute from Haneda to Tokyo takes just half an hour.
  • NRT - Narita Airport. Narita Airport is situated not in Tokyo, but in Chiba prefecture, 65 km away. A train ride to Tokyo from Narita is just over an hour long.

All Nippon Airways, Cathay Pacific and Japan Airlines fly from Hong Kong to both Haneda and Narita. Ethiopian Airlines, Hong Kong Airlines, Jetstar Japan and Vanilla Air fly only to Narita while Cathay Dragon flies only to Haneda.

Why Fly First Class?

Travelling by first class and business class is an experience that simply transcends sitting in an economy seat for any considerable period. For the four-and-a-half-hour journey between Hong Kong and Tokyo, premium class seats go a long way.

The ample legroom, wide armrests and additional personal space accorded by the seating layout gives you the ability to rest, enjoy the entertainment system and even work comfortably if you are travelling for business.

Seoul has two international airports, Incheon and Gimpo. However, all flights originating in Hong Kong fly exclusively to Incheon, 48 km from Seoul.

Incheon Airport (ICN) is an amazing facility – it has won the Airport Councils International award for best airport 11 years in row, every year since 2015. The staggering array of entertainment options are one reason – there is an ice skating rink, golf course, casino and spa for passengers to while the time away.

First class travel has always been one of the most prestigious clubs of which you can choose to be a part. While air travel itself has become accessible to larger proportions of the population, elite travel has always kept pace with those developments.

Advantages of Flying First Class

What was first class air service in the years gone by has become a part of regular travel, but only because first class travel of today offers an experience in the air - which actually starts on the ground – that travelers of yesteryear would never have imagined possible.

There is not just the incomparable service that equals that of the best hotels, it is also the fact that many amenities you would assume are limited to hotels are made available to you while you cruise far above the surface of the earth.

Gourmet food is virtually a given on any airline in first class. The meals are usually accompanied by wine specially chosen to complement your status. Major airlines nowadays even offer the option of double beds within enclosed cabins that offer comfort comparable to those found in leading hotels.

Two airlines fly direct from New York to Munich - Lufthansa and United.

Lufthansa operates two flights, one from JFK International Airport (JFK) and the other from Newark's Liberty International Airport (EWR). United operates a single flight from Newark Airport. All three flights land at Munich International Airport (MUC).

The Lufthansa flight from JFK is 8 hours 5 minutes long, the same as the United flight from Newark. However, the Lufthansa flight from Newark takes a marginally shorter time than both at 7 hours and 55 minutes.

Lufthansa operates the Airbus A340 on this sector and offers first class seats while United uses the Boeing 767 and has business class but no first class. However, all three have lie-flat seats for the overnight journey. All three flights also offer in-flight Wi-Fi.

The cruising altitude of the Lufthansa planes is 11,280 m while United’s Boeing flies at 10,680 m.

Airports in Munich

There is a single international airport in Munich, the Munich International Airport located 18 miles (29 kilometers) northeast of Munich. Its official name is Franz Josef Strauss Airport.

The facility is well connected by road and rail to the city of Munich. A train or bus to the main central station takes approximately 45 minutes. The journey takes about 35 minutes by car.

Advantages of Flying First Class

It may seem unfortunate that there are no direct flights between Sydney and Frankfurt. However, that is actually a positive as it allows you to truly stretch your legs midway through a journey with a total flight time of more than 20 hours.

The shortest complete trip clocks in at 22 hours flat and is offered by Thai Airways with a 1hour 25-minute stopover in Bangkok. You can also use Singapore airlines and enjoy a two-and-a-half-hour layover in Singapore's Changi Airport with their offering that lands in Frankfurt in just under 24 hours.

Lufthansa also offers two options from Sydney to Frankfurt that are completed in less than a day but these require you to use either British Airways or Singapore Airlines on the second leg of the journey.

Singapore Airlines the most luxurious option on this journey. First class passengers do not just get lie-flat beds but individual suites on the Airbus A380 on both legs of the journey. Inside these creations of French luxury yacht designer Jean-Jacques Coste, you get a chaise lounge and large table transform the space in your cabin into a discussion or dining area. The first leg to Singapore takes 8 hours 20 minutes, and the second to Frankfurt, 12 hours 50 minutes.

The offering from Thai Airways uses quad-jets on both legs, a Boeing 747 for the 9 hours 20 min from Sydney to Bangkok, then an Airbus A380-800 for the 11 hours 15 minutes to Frankfurt.

Airports in Frankfurt

All flights from Sydney to Frankfurt land at the city’s only airport, Frankfurt Airport (FRA). It is one of Europe’s largest and busiest airports, handling over 1,300 flights every day and over 60 million passengers every year.

As expected, both because of its status as Germany’s busiest airport and German efficiency, Frankfurt is very well connected to the transport network within the country. The Autobahn intersection leads directly to the airport’s grounds while the local and regional rail networks connect the facility to major destinations all around Germany.

It takes just 12 minutes to reach Frankfurt Central Station by rail and just slightly longer to reach the city by car.

Advantages of Flying First Class

Better still, you enjoy the perks of traveling in premium class even before you step aboard a plane – accelerated check-in, quality lounges and preferential boarding privileges will put a smile on your face as soon as you reach the airport.

If you intend to travel from New York to Paris in a first class seat, only the French national carrier, Air France, operates direct flights with that option.

These are overnight flights that have a scheduled flight time of 7 hours 25 minutes to complete the journey from New York's JFK International Airport (JFK) to Paris's Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG). Air France uses A38-800 quad-jets that operate at a cruising altitude of 11,280 m.

If you opt for business class, there is a lot more variety on offer. Besides the Air France flights that offer both first class and business class, legacy carriers like British Airways, United and American Airlines, and all-business airline, La Compagnie also ply this route.

The La Compagnie flight is the shortest at just 7 hours 15 minutes long on its Boeing 757-200 plane from Newark’s Liberty International Airport (EWR) to Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG) in Paris. It features angled flat seats. United also flies this route but takes 10 minutes longer and makes up with seats that lie completely flat. It cruises at an altitude of 10,050 m on Boeing 767-400 twin-jets.

American Airlines and British Airways both depart New York from Newark Airport but while the American 767-300 lands at Charles de Gaulle, the British 757-200 lands at Paris Orly Airport (ORY). Both flights take 7 and a half hours and give business passengers lie-flat seats.

Airports in Paris

There are three airports in Paris, but only two that are served by flights from New York – Charles de Gaulle (CDG) and Orly (ORY).

CDG in Roissy is situated about 35 km north of Paris city center and the journey by road will take you just over half an hour. Orly, to the south of the city is much closer, just 13 km away so the trip can be completed in less than 15 minutes in normal traffic.

Charles de Gaulle airport is also connected to Paris by a high-speed rail system. On the other hand, you will have to catch the light rail system, Orlyval, to RER, the Paris urban transit rail system.

If you are looking for a direct flight from New York to London, two airlines offer you first class seats on your journey. They are American Airlines and British Airways.

American Airlines only flies this sector originating from New York's JFK International Airport (JFK). The British national carrier gives you the option of departing from New York at either JFK or Newark's Liberty International Airport (EWR). They both land at London Heathrow Airport (LHR).

Your only option to fly from New York to London's Gatwick Airport (LGW) is British Airways. BA completes the journey in exactly 7 hours on a Boring 777 with a cruising altitude of 11,880 m.

Heathrow is closer to central London, situated just 15 miles west of the city while Gatwick is 30 miles to the south. However, Gatwick is less crowded and is better organized than its bigger cousin which is the world's busiest international airport.

Both airports are well-connected to the rail and transport system, and most travelers prefer one over the other due to the proximity to their destination in London.

From the expedited check-in, complimentary luxury lounge access, priority boarding at the airport to the fine wine and gourmet cuisine, exciting entertainment options and beds almost as large as your own on board, first class travel is simply one great discovery after another.

British Airways and American Airlines both give you the option of flying in style in first class direct from Los Angeles to London. All of American Airlines' flights on this sector are performed using the Boeing 777 while the British Airline employs the Airbus A380.

While the two airlines offer lie-flat seats, the British Airways A380-800 quad-jet does not have the option of in-flight Wi-Fi while some the American airline's flights using Boeing 777-300 ERs do.

They are also similar in that they both take off from Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) and touch down at London's Heathrow Airport (LHR). Travel in first class on these two flights and you will reach your destination in 10 hours 30 minutes.

If you plan to travel in business class instead, the range of options is considerably wider. Besides the AA and BA flights, United, Air New Zealand and Virgin Atlantic also fly direct from Los Angeles to Heathrow.

United and Virgin Atlantic both utilize the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, cruising at 10,680 m to complete the leg in ten and a half hours. Air New Zealand flies the same Boeing 777-300Ers as United and spends the same 10 hours 30 minutes in the air. It has a cruising altitude of 10,050 meters.

Airports in London

There are five airports in the English capital. However, all direct flights from Los Angeles land only at London Heathrow International Airport (LHR), the busiest airport in the world.

Its two runways and four terminals handle 72 million passengers annually, as well as 1.4 million tons of cargo. Planes operated by over 80 airlines fly to and from 180 worldwide destinations.

As would be expected from an airport of its stature, Heathrow is very well connected to the city of London via road and rail. Heathrow Express trains leave every fifteen minutes for Paddington Station, and arrive at their destination in the same time. It is connected to the South West lines as well as the London Underground systems, too.

Advantages of Flying First Class

First class and business class tickets put you into this world of amazing experiences.

The distance between Sydney and Paris is just shy of 17,000 kilometers, or just over 10,500 miles. That is too great a distance to be covered in a direct flight and you will have to take a connecting flight with at least one stop in the journey.

The shortest time that you can complete your trip from Sydney to Paris is with Singapore Airlines which will have you in the French capital in just over 24 hours after you take from Australia.

It is also the most luxurious; gone are the lie-flat seats, replaced by an enclosed individual suite with a sliding door and blinds for the ultimate privacy. Inside, a 23-inch LCD TV gives you over 1,000 entertainment options as you relax on a chaise lounge 35 inches wide. The seat does not become the bed - that is an entire unit on its own. If you are travelling with a partner, adjacent suites combine for a full-size double bed which will have you skeptical that you are on a plane.

The flight from Sydney to Singapore takes 8 hours 20 minutes, before a 3-hour layover at Singapore's award-winning Changi Airport. The second leg is 13 hours 20 minutes long.

The best price for a trip from Sydney to Paris comes from Thai Airways. The entire journey takes 29 hours because of the layover in Bangkok that is 7 hours 45 minutes long. However, time zone differences mean you technically land in 21 hours.

Thai Airways uses the Boeing 747 on the first leg of the journey and the Airbus A380 on the second. They both feature lie-flat seats.

Airports in Paris

Paris is home to three international airports but only two are served by flights originating in Sydney– Charles de Gaulle (CDG) and Orly (ORY).

CDG is approximately 35 km north of the city and the journey takes just over half an hour by road. Orly lies to the south of the city and is much closer at just 13 km by road; you can reach Paris in less than 15 minutes at most times.

Charles de Gaulle Airport connects to Paris by a high speed rail system. A light rail system connects Orlyval, to RER, the French capital’s urban transit rail system.

Although New York and Dubai are both major tourist hubs, certain restrictions mean that only Emirates Airways, the national carrier of the United Arab Emirates (U.A.E.) where Dubai is located, flies direct from New York to that city.

Taking off from New York’s JFK Airport (JFK) and arriving at Dubai International Airport (DXB), the flight duration is between 12 hours 30 minutes and 12 hours 50 minutes. Emirates operates a specially-fitted Airbus A380 on this sector, which allows it to provide individual suites to each first class passenger.

Airports in Dubai

Direct flights from New York all land at Dubai International Airport (DXB), the busiest airport in the world by passenger traffic, which also has a series of records to its name.

The massive complex is built over 2,900 hectares (7,200 acres) of land, making it the largest airline hub in the Middle East. Its Terminal 3 is the world's largest airport terminal and also the largest building in the world by floor space.

The safety and security standards in place are extraordinary - all foreign passengers arriving at DXB (and every airport in the U.A.E.) are subject to retinal scans. A state-of-the-art drugs detection system can be triggered by as little as 0.001 grams of illegal drugs on a person.

Advantages of Flying First Class from New York to Amsterdam

Flying first class can be addictive. The combination of great service that anticipates and meets all your needs, a vast range of amenities designed to make every aspect of air travel enjoyable, and comfort and luxury comparable to elite hotels creates an enticing mix.

Airlines are constantly upgrading and improving the facilities and services they offer on board. Lie-flat beds are ubiquitous and only getting bigger and more comfortable. Certain carriers allow you to pick an acclaimed chef of your choice to prepare your meals.

Boredom is virtually impossible considering the extensive range of music, audio books and movies available to be enjoyed on big flat screens and using premium headphones.

The Dutch flag carrier, KLM, United Airlines and Delta all fly direct daily from New York to Amsterdam in the Netherlands. KLM operates solely from JFK Airport and United only from Newark (EWR), while Delta flies from both. There are altogether between three and six flights every day.

The shortest duration offering is from KLM at 7 hours 15 minutes. All three airlines offer lie-flat seats but the American carriers also offer inflight Wi-Fi. KLM and United operate Airbus A330s; KLM also has Boeing 777s and 787s plying the route while United uses Boeing 757s.

 

Airports in Amsterdam

Amsterdam is served by a single airport - Amsterdam Airport Schiphol (AMS). Located nine miles (14.5 km) southwest of the city, it is the nation's busiest airport and the fifth largest in Europe.

The Amsterdam rail network makes getting from the airport to the city very convenient, especially with a stop right under Schiphol. Trains leave for the city round the clock and complete the journey in about 20 minutes.

Buses and taxis are easily available and will have you in Amsterdam usually within half an hour.

The New York to Stockholm direct route is only offered by a single carrier - Scandinavian Airlines Systems, or SAS. These are operated daily aboard the Airbus A330-300 twin jet plane.

Passengers looking to fly the route in a premium seat will have to settle with business class. However, SAS does offer lie-fat seats, inflight Wi-Fi, in-seat and USB power and video on demand even in their business cabin.

Flying at 529 mph and cruising at 11,280 feet, the journey has a duration of 7 hours 55 minutes.

Stockholm Arlanda Airport (ARN) is the only international airport serving the city of Stockholm. Located 23 miles outside the national capital, it is the country's largest international airport and the third largest in Scandinavia.

Buses and taxis are easily available and will transport you to the city in about 40 minutes. Two railway stations at the airport allow you to complete the journey in about half that time.

Advantages of Flying First Class from New York to Madrid

First class travel is synonymous with opulence and luxury. However, first class travelers are usually drawn more to the convenience that the experience offers than anything else.

The first class experience is marked by unsurpassed attention to detail at every step. Exclusive check-in counters make the process a breeze. You can then make your way to a plush executive lounge to wait for your flight. Some airports even offer special counters which expedite immigration checks. Priority boarding completes the calm, effortless pre-flight stage.

On board, the incomparably comfortable seating is complemented by a wide range of entertainment options and the excellent, personalized service. Many airways give you the option of choosing your own menu, prepared by acclaimed chefs.

The New York to Madrid, Spain direct route is a popular one and there are several flights available daily, operated by numerous airways. However, they all only offer business class cabins, not first class.

The flight of the shortest duration is Iberia's 7 hour 5-minute journey aboard its Airbus A340. Its lie-flat seats are good while inflight Wi-Fi, in-seat & USB power and video on demand sweeten the deal.

United also gives passengers the same amenities but its Boeing 767 flight is slightly longer at 7 hours 15 minutes. American Airlines offers the same flight time on the same aircraft type but does not offer Wi-Fi on board.

All these flights take off from JFK Airport and land at Madrid’s Adolfo Suarez Madrid-Barajas Airport (MAD).

Airports in Madrid

The Spanish capital of Madrid is home to one civilian international airport, the Adolfo Suarez Madrid-Barajas Airport (MAD). Just 8 miles (13 km) from Madrid's historic city center and 6 miles (9 km) from its financial district, it is the perfect spot from which to start your Spanish holiday.

The Madrid Metro line links the airport to the financial district, and also connects to the Spanish railway network. A bus service to Atocha Station runs 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.

Advantages of Flying First Class from New York to Moscow

Flying first class is the epitome of luxury travel. Few experiences can offer a comparable level of sophistication and extravagance. It does not matter by which facet you judge its standards – the cuisine, entertainment, amenities, comfort and service are all a cut above the rest.

There is no shortage of direct flights between New York City and Moscow; the Russian national airway, Aeroflot, operates three flights on this route every day of the week.

All Aeroflot's direct flights to Moscow originate from New York City's JFK Airport (JFK) and terminate at Moscow's Sheremetyevo International Airport (SVO). The duration of the flights is between 9 hours 5 minutes and 9 hours 20 minutes.

The late evening flight is operated using a Boeing 777 and has lie-flat seats while the other two use Airbus A330s that only have angled flat seats. All the flights have onboard Wi-Fi and in-seat power.

Airports in Moscow

There are two airports serving the Russian capital - Sheremetyevo International Airport (SVO) and Moscow Domodedovo Airport (DME). However, direct flights from New York all land at SVO.

SVO is situated 18 miles (29 km) northwest of the city. Handling 32 million passengers annually, it is the busiest airport in the Russian Federation.

A rail network connects the airport to downtown Moscow. If you have travelled in premium class to Moscow by air, you can continue the experience with business class coaches on the Aeroexpress trains. The journey takes about 35 minutes.

A new highway network lets you travel between the city and the airport in about 10 minutes.

Emirates offers the ultimate luxury of individual suites if you choose to travel with them in first class. However, in business class they only have angled flat seats and, in this respect, Delta's lie-flat business class seats have the advantage.

The other point in Delta's favor is the provision of inflight Wi-Fi on its Boeing 767s which Emirates’ Boeing 777s do not offer, even in first class.

However, Emirates completes the journey in 9 hours 10 minutes flying from Newark Airport (EWR) whereas the duration of the Delta flight flying from JFK Airport is considerably longer at 9 hours 53 minutes.

Airports in Athens

Eleftherios Venizelos (ATH) is located 12 miles (20 km) east of this fantastically historic city. Handling over 20 million passengers annually, it is Greece's largest and busiest airport.

Besides taxis and buses, you may also travel from the airport to the city via the rail and metro station located opposite the main terminal building.

The airport is renowned for its hexagonal terminal design which ingeniously reduces the distance from aircraft to terminal exit to as little as 98 feet (30 meters). It serves about 22 million passengers annually.

Superior seating, excellent food and wine, and the best service on the ground and in the air make your time traveling a most pleasant one.

Two airlines offer non-stop flights on the New York to Beijing route – United and Air China.

However, only Air China offers first class cabins on this sector. It operates from JFK Airport in the United States and lands at Beijing Capital International Airport (PEK) in the Chinese capital. On the other hand, United Airlines offers business class seats on its flights to Beijing which originate at Newark Airport (EWR) and land at PEK.

United's route using the Boeing 777-200 takes 14 hours to complete while the Chinese Airline's Boeing 777-300ER flights are marginally shorter at 13 hours 50 minutes. The Air China flight cruises at 573 mph at an altitude of 9,450 m while United uses an airway at an altitude of 8,850 m and flies at 540 mph.

Both airlines offer lie-flat seats but United's cabins have the added advantage on in-flight Wi-Fi for your convenience.

Airports in Beijing

There are currently two airports in Beijing. The first is the Beijing Capital International Airport (PEK) while Beijing Nanyuan Airport (NAY) performs the role of the city’s secondary airport. A new major international airport, the Beijing Daxing International Airport is expected to be completed and in operation by late 2018.

Beijing Capital International Airport is one of the largest and busiest airports in the world. Inter-terminal transport across the vast complex is via automated people movers and regular buses.

The Beijing Subway system has a dedicated Airport Express Line that connects two of the three terminals directly to the city. A journey from the city to the airport takes approximately 20 minutes.

There are also direct feeder bus services from several points within the city of Beijing to the airport, as well as to major neighboring cities from the airport. Three separate expressways lead to PEK; note that they are all toll roads.

Athens is one of the oldest cities in the world. One of the shining torches of modernity in the city is provided by the Eleftherios Venizelos Airport (ATH), Greece’s largest and busiest.

British Airways is the fastest choice at 12 hours 50 minutes, which consists of an initial leg from LAX to London Heathrow Airport (LHR) that takes 10 hours 20 minutes followed by a 1 hour 10-minute layover. The final leg takes just 1 hour 20 minutes.

Airports in Amsterdam

Amsterdam Airport Schiphol (AMS) lies to the southwest of the Dutch city and is the only civilian airport that serves its residents. Not only is it the busiest airport in the country, it is also the fifth largest in all of Europe.

The 9 miles (14.5 km) distance from the city center is easily and quickly covered by an efficient road and rail network. The journey by road takes approximately half an hour and just 20 minutes by train. The latter option is especially convenient with a station right under the airport.

Emirates is the only airline that flies direct between Los Angeles and Dubai. Their A380 aircraft flies at an altitude of 10,350 m and at a speed of 570 mph, covering the distance in just under 16 hours.

The Los Angeles to Dubai first class experience with Emirates is one of the most iconic of the entire modern flying era. The specially-designed Airbus A380 is equipped with all manner of amenities, including a shower, stand-up bars in first and business class, and amenity kits that put many hotels to shame.

The airline also offers chauffer pick-ups to all first class and business class passengers. Their airport lounges give you a goof preview of the on-board experience as you wait for your flight.

Airports in Dubai

The Dubai International Airport (DXB) is the busiest airport in the world in terms of commercial passenger traffic.

Built over a space of 2,900 hectares (7,200 acres), it is a marvel of engineering that has won a slew of awards and broken several records on the way. Its Terminal 3 building, which receives the bulk of international passengers is the world’s largest terminal and also the largest building by floor space.

Passengers planning to travel to the U.A.E., where Dubai is located, should be aware that all foreign civilians arriving in the country are subject to retinal scans at immigration. There are also extremely precise drug-detection systems in place which can identify as little as 0.001 grams of illegal drugs on a person.

Advantages of Flying First Class

For most people, flying first class will forever be a dream out of reach. If you are one of the fortunate few who is privy to this world of luxury and opulence, you know that it is one of the most exquisite experiences that anyone can have.

Airlines lay out the red carpet for first class and business class passengers even before they board. Some offer chauffeur limousine services for pick-up, while priority check-in and boarding, and access to opulent lounges are standard fare.

This excellent treatment on the ground is just a preview of the onboard luxury that awaits. Lose yourself in the fine wine and chef-prepared food, and drift off to sleep in an enclosed suite while being entertained on a large personal screen connected to noise-canceling earphones.

No airline flies direct from Los Angeles to Milan but there are ample options available with a single layover that are extremely convenient.

Of these, SwissAir's offering is the most luxurious. While other airlines do have lie-flat seats, SwissAir gives first class passengers an enclosed suite for the first part of the journey from LAX to Zurich Airport (ZRH). This leg takes 10 hours 55 minutes, and after a 2 hour 5-minute layover, the second leg of just 50 minutes begins.

Lufthansa offers the quickest option of just 13 hours 25 minutes overall even though the total flight time is longer than SwissAir's offering. This is because there is just a 1 hour 20-minute layover at Frankfurt between the 10 hour 55-minute leg from LAX and the 1 hour 10-minute leg to Milan (MXP).

Airports in Milan

Two international commercial airports serve the Italian city of Milan. The first is Milan Malpensa Airport (MXP) and the second, Linate International Airport (LIN). International flights connecting from Los Angeles are split roughly equally between the two.

MXP is the second-busiest airport in the country after Rome. It is situated 30 miles (49 km) northwest of Milan. Located 29 miles (41 km) from the city, LIN is the larger of the two. However, they both handle about 20 million passengers a year.

Regular express trains run every half hour to their terminal stations while two daily high-speed services connect them to the larger region. The airports are also accessible by highways and motorways.

Singapore Airlines and British Airways first class cabins offer lie-flat seats, as does Qantas business class. Scoot, however, only offers extra reclining seats in business class.

The Singaporean transport system is one of the best in the world and very affordable, too. The MRT subway system has a dedicated airport line while a reliable bus network will take you to the city within 40 minutes.

The world’s best car rental companies have offices in Changi Airport and offer a variety of vehicle options. However, automobile prices are very high in the country and this carries over to rental rates. Most travelers find that the public transport system is suitable for their needs.

The option with the shortest flight time is offered by Singapore Airlines and its subsidiary, SilkAir. It involves a flight time of just 11 hours 5 minutes, including a brief stop of 55 minutes at Singapore's Changi Airport.

The first leg is particularly luxurious, with each first class passenger receiving an individual suite on the SIA Airbus A380. The second, 11 hour 20-minute leg offers only business class and has standard recliner seats.

Thai Airways has a similar offering - first class with lie-flat seats on the 9 hour 25-minute journey to Bangkok, and an angled seat in business class to Phuket. The total flight time is 11 hours 49 minutes.

If you wish to travel in business class all the way, Malaysia Airlines will get you from Sydney to Phuket in 15 hours 35 minutes, a time inflated by a 5 hour 35-minute layover in Kuala Lumpur. While it offers lie-flat seats on the first leg, you will have to contend with a standard recliner seat on the journey from the Malaysian capital to Phuket.

Airports in Phuket

Phuket is a major tourist destination in Thailand and is served by the Phuket International Airport (HKT) situated 20 miles (32 km) north of the City.

It is Thailand's third-busiest airport and sees more than 15 million passenger movements every year. The Phuket-Singapore route is the busiest with almost a million passengers traveling between the two destinations annually.

There are two public terminals on the complex, one for international flights and the other for domestic ones. There is a third terminal used exclusively for charter flights.

item.summary: Flying in first class is like continuing the luxurious life to which you are accustomed, only 30,000 feet in the air. You will have access to the same quality of superior gourmet food and wine, and receive the same personal attention from staff form the moment you arrive at check-in.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

If you want to flying to Vietnam from Sydney, you will first have to decide which of the major cities in this Southeast Asian country will be your destination. Ho Chi Minh City, the Vietnamese capital located in the south, and the city of Hanoi in the north are the two most popular choices for Aussie travelers.

There are no direct flights from Sydney to either Ho Chi Minh or Hanoi in first class. Vietnam Airlines offers business class seats, though, and the journey time is 8 hours 15 minutes to the capital and 9 hours 35 minutes to Hanoi. Business class passengers on Vietnam Airlines enjoy the space and comfort of lie-flat seats on board the Boeing 787s used on both routes.

Airports in Vietnam

There are 11 civilian airports in Vietnam currently capable of handling international flights and they are spread across the country.

Ho Chi Minh City is served by Tan Son Nhat International Airport (SGN), Vietnam’s busiest airport. Nearly 33 million passengers arrived or departed from here in 2016. Because there is urban sprawl around the airport, it has limited expansion potential and will be replaced by a new airport in the near future.

Noi Bai International Airport (HAN) in Hanoi is Vietnam's second-largest airport, and is located 21 miles (35 km) northeast of the city center. It handled close to 21 million passengers in 2016. Noi Ban received a major overhaul in 2015, which led to it receiving the ‘World's Most Improved Airport’ award from Skytrax in 2016.

item.name: Flights to Fiji from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Fiji from Sydney
item.sub_title: Comfortable flights with IFlyFirstClass to Fiji from Sydney
item.summary: There has never been a time when simply the phrase ‘first class air travel’ has not managed to evoke images of opulent luxury and service beyond compare. This was true in the pioneering years of air travel and continues to be the trend today.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

No other way of traveling vast distances combines speed, comfort and style the way that first class and business class travel do. Passengers have access to superior food, wine and entertainment options, which makes for an unforgettable experience in the air.

There are direct flights between Sydney and Fiji but none that offer first class seats - you will have to settle for business class. There are two Fijian destinations to which you can fly - Nadi and Suva.

Fiji Airways and Virgin Australia fly direct to Nadi. The Fijian airline completes the journey in a time of 3 hours 55 minutes in an Airbus A330 while Virgin takes 4 hours 15 minutes in a Boeing 737. The Boeing has standard recliner seats while the Airbus has angled flat seats. In the air, Virgin flies at 518 mph at an altitude of 10,680 m while Fiji Airways does so at 540 mph at 11,280 m.

If you intend to fly directly to Suva, your only option is Fiji Airways. The journey takes 4 hours 20 minutes on board their Boeing 737 with standard recliner seats in business class.

Airports in Fiji

It is amazing that in a country as small as Fiji, there are 16 airports and airfields that regularly receive commercial airline flights. Of these, only Nadi International Airport (NAN) on the western side of Fiji's main island, and Nausori International Airport (SUV) on its eastern side, cater to international flights. The other 14 provide air links from regional areas to Nadi, Suva or both.

Nadi Airport handles approximately 97% of the international passenger traffic while Nausori caters to the rest. In 2014, just under 2 million passengers landed at or departed from Nadi.

item.name: Flights to Hawaii from Sydney
item.title: Flights from Sydney to Hawaii
item.sub_title: Comfortable flights with IFlyFirstClass
item.summary: No travel experience compares to the thrill of luxury and opulence that is the realm of the first class cabin. There is gourmet food, fine wine, and unending entertainment choices to enjoy through large personal screens and premium headsets.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

If you are traveling a long-distance route like that between Sydney and Hawaii, first class and business class seats can make a significant difference. The duration of the journey depends on your specific destination in Hawaii.

There are four main international airports in the U.S. state of Hawaii - Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu, Oahu, Kahului Airport (OGG) on Maui Island, Kona International Airport (KOA) on Hawaii Island, and Lihue Airport (LIH) on Kauai Island.

Of these, there are only direct flights from Sydney to Honolulu Airport (HNL). This is a 9 hours 55-minute flight on a Hawaiian Airlines Airbus A330. The plane flies at 535 mph at an altitude of 12,510 m. It is the quickest way to reach Hawaii from Sydney.

The only Hawaiian destination that offers first class cabins all the way is Kailua, and the flights are a collaboration between Korean Air and Hawaiian Airlines. However, the journey takes a time of over 26 hours, making layovers in Seoul and Honolulu.

On the other hand, Hawaiian Airlines will complete the trip in 12 hours 36 minutes, including the layover time of 1 hour 52 minutes in Honolulu, if you are willing to forego first class on the final leg.

Airports in Hawaii

In 2015, 14 airports in the U.S. state of Hawaii had passengers boarding domestic and international commercial flights. Of these, the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu on Oahu Island handled approximately 9.5 million passengers, almost double all the others put together.

The second major airport is Kahului Airport (OGG) on Maui Island, which saw just over 3 million passengers. It is followed by Kona International Airport (KOA) in Kailua-Kona on Hawaii Island (aka Big Island), and Lihue Airport (LIH) in Lihue on Kauai Island. They handled 1.4 million and 1.3 million passengers respectively.

item.name: Flights to Bali from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Bali from Sydney
item.sub_title: Comfortable first and business class flights with IFlyFirstClass to Bali from Sydney
item.summary: If you are used to the finer things in life, why compromise when you travel? First class travel is the epitome of luxury in the air with its excellent service, the best gourmet food and vintage wines yours to enjoy to your heart’s content.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

There are few direct flights from Sydney to Asian destinations that have first class cabins, and Bali does not buck the trend. However, three airlines offer business class seating for you to begin your Bali getaway - Virgin Australia, Garuda Indonesia and Qantas.

Qantas offers the quickest option at 6 hours 25 minutes, but Garuda and Virgin are only fractionally slower by 5 minutes and 10 minutes respectively.

Both Australian airways offer standard recliner seats on this route but Garuda has the superior option of angled flat seats. It is also the only one to offer Wi-Fi connectivity on board. This is because the Indonesian airline uses the Airbus A330 while the other two fly the Boeing 737 on this route.

The Virgin and Qantas Boeing 737-800s fly at a speed of 518 mph and at an altitude of 10,350 m. Garuda's Airbus A330-300 flies at 540 mph and cruises at a height of 10,980 m.

Airports in Bali

Bali is a major international tourism destination but is served by a single airport, the Ngurah Rai International Airport (DPS). It is commonly referred to as the Denpasar International Airport. The complex is located at the southern tip of Bali island, a scant 2.5 km from the famous Kuta Beach.

DPS is the nation's third-busiest airport, and handles both domestic and international flights. It catered to over 10 million passengers in the first half of 2017 alone. However, DPS is nearing its maximum capacity and will likely be replaced by another airport within the coming decade.

The airport's architecture draws heavily from the island's Hindu culture, and there are statues of mythological creatures from the Ramayana within the complex. Lounges contain children's playgrounds, movie theaters and massage facilities.

Because Bali was the target of two previous Islamist terrorist attacks, over 800 security personnel are employed by the airport.

item.name: Flights to Bangkok from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Bangkok from Sydney
item.sub_title: Business and first class tickets to Bangkok from Sydney
item.summary: First class travel is not about just getting to your destination; it is about an experience that transcends the norm. Premium travel focuses on the luxury to which you are accustomed and ensures that you do not have to forego it simply because you are soaring above the clouds.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

Gourmet food prepared by renowned chefs are complemented by good wine and peerless service. Your comfort is of prime concern and individual suites give you the privacy and comfort of a hotel room.

Thai Airways and Emirates are the only two airlines that offer first class cabins on the Sydney to Bangkok route.

However, Emirates has the more luxurious option with individual suites in first class and lie-flat seats in business class aboard its Airbus A380 craft. Thai Airways uses Boeing 747s, which has lie flat seats in first class and angled flat seats in business.

Both airlines complete the journey with the same flight time of 9 hours 25 minutes.

The Airbus cruises at a speed of 555 mph and 10,980 m above the earth. Thai's Boeing flies slightly faster at 567 mph and at an altitude of 10,350 m.

Airports in Bangkok

There are two international airports that serve the city of Bangkok. One is Don Mueang International Airport (DMK) and the other is Suvarnabhumi Airport (BKK).

Don Mueang is one of the world's oldest commercial airports, and the oldest of Asia's airports still in operation. As of March 2012, it is supposed to transition into the hub for low-cost and domestic flights while Suvarnabhumi becomes the airport for international arrivals and departures.

However, Don Mueang currently still handles both domestic and international flights, albeit at different terminals. It is located 17.6 miles (28.2 km) from Bangkok.

Suvarnabhumi Airport is commonly called New Bangkok Airport and has been in operation since 2006. It is located 16 miles (25 km) east of Bangkok city and is known for the having the world's tallest free-standing control tower at 434 feet (132.2 meters).

It handled 55.9 million passengers in 2016.

item.name: Flights to Samoa from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Samoa from Sydney
item.sub_title: Comfortable flights with IFlyFirstClass to Samoa
item.summary: Travelers do not simply choose first class and business class travel because of minor advantages like larger personal space and better comfort. No, the appeal of premium class travel is in the entirety of the experience, in the knowledge that great effort has been invested to ensure that you have the most pleasant experience both in the air and on the ground.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

An essential part of that may be the extra legroom, but is really the personalized service, the VIP treatment, accelerated check-in and preferential boarding.

There is only one option for premium class travelers to Samoa if they wish to avoid a layover - Virgin Australia's VA79. This is a bi-weekly flight that flies from Sydney to Faleolo International Airport every Tuesday and Friday.

The flight time is 5 hours 30 minutes on board a Boeing 737. There is no first class but business class cabins are equipped with standard recliner seats.

If you do not mind a layover or would prefer to break you journey into shorter legs, Fiji Airways operates a flight that travels from Sydney to Nadi Airport (NAN) in Fiji in 4 hours before a 3-hour transit period. The second leg to Apia takes under 3 hours for a total journey time of 9 hours 35 minutes.

Airports in Samoa

Samoa, or the Independent State of Samoa, as separate from American Samoa, is a nation made up of two islands - Upolu and Savai'i - that comprise 99% of its total land mass.

There are two international airports on Upolu - Faleolo International Airport (APW) and Fagali'i Airport (FGI). The former handles the bulk of international passenger traffic while the latter handles only regional flights to and from Pago Pago and American Samoa.

Savai'i is home to Asau Airport (AAU), which handles only domestic flights.

item.name: Flights to Bora Bora from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Bora Bora from Sydney
item.sub_title: First or business class, best prices and deals with IFlyFirstClass
item.summary: Flying in first class or business class is a thrill for the simple fact that airlines invest considerable effort in making the experience a uniquely pleasant one. The preferential treatment begins even before you board with expedited check-in, exclusive lounge access and simplified formal procedures.
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

On board, enjoy good food and wine amidst plush settings while being entertained by the latest music, movies and digital publications.

Flying in premium class is enjoyable, but Bora Bora is one of the most remote places in the world and getting there is an adventure in itself. There are certainly no direct flights from Sydney - all flights that land on Bora Bora originate in one of the islands of French Polynesia.

Flying from Sydney, you will have to make at least three stops before you reach Bora Bora. There are no options to fly in first class on any of the four legs of the journey. However, there are business class cabins available on the first leg from Sydney to Auckland which lasts 3 hours 15 minutes.

You have two options to reach Bora Bora, the shorter of which takes 21 hours 10 minutes and the other that takes 40 minutes longer. The first two legs for both choices are identical. You first fly from Sydney to Auckland in 3 hours 15 minutes, then transit there for 2 hours 5 minutes. You then take the 5-hour flight to Papeete.

The Papeete stopover is 9 hours 30 minutes for the shorter option, after which you take a 40-minute flight to Huahine. There is a 15-minute layover before you fly to Motu Mute Airport (BOB) on Bora Bora.

With the longer journey, the Papeete layover is 10 hours 10 minutes long. This is followed by a 15-minute flight to Moorea (MOZ), a 15-minute layover, and then a 50-minute flight to Bora Bora’s Motu Mute Airport.

With either option, all legs but the first are on turbo-prop aircraft operated by Air Tahiti. The timings given here are based on beginning your journey with a LATAM Airlines flight from Sydney to Auckland. Other airways also fly this initial route but this option saves you the most time.

Airports in Bora Bora

There is only one airport on Boora Bora – Motu Mute (BOB). Located on an island in the middle of a lagoon, it is equipped only to handle the small propeller craft operated by Air Tahiti. You will need to transfer by boat to get from the airport island to the main island.

item.name: Flights to Dubai from Sydney
item.title: Flights to Dubai from Sydney
item.sub_title: Visit Dubai from Sydney with I Fly First Class
item.summary: It would have been unimaginable even very recently to fly on a commercial passenger liner and have an individual, enclosed suite for the journey. How many would have predicted not too long ago that you could have two showers while cruising high above the earth between two continents?
item.body:
Advantages of Flying First Class

Yet, this is where first class travel is today, astounding us with the sheer ingenuity that has been invested in making the travel experience unlike any other. Airlines even feature buffets and bars at which you can sit with friends while you fly. The food and wine are exceptional, and service seldom, if ever, leaves room for improvement.

You can have a taste of all this, and more, if you decide to fly from Sydney to Dubai.

The national carriers of Australia and the U.A.E. both give you the options of direct flights between the two cities. While both airlines use the Airbus A380-800 quad-jet on this route, there is a difference in their cabin layouts.

While Qantas features lie-flat seats in first class, which are extremely comfortable in their own right, Emirates goes the extra mile by giving each first class passenger their own individual enclosed suite. Both airlines offer lie-flat beds in business class.

The flight times are virtually identical - 14 hours 20 minutes for Emirates and 14 hours 45 minutes for Qantas. The former flies at 560 mph at an altitude of 9,750 m while the latter cruises at 548 mph at an altitude of 10,980 m.

Airports in Dubai

All flights between the cities of Sydney and Dubai take off and land at Dubai International Airport (DXB) in the Arab nation. It is the busiest airport in the world by passenger numbers, and is also listed in the Guinness Book of World Records for a number of other feats.

DXB is the largest airline hub in the Middle East, built over a land area of 2,900 hectares (7,200 acres). Dubai Airport’s Terminal 3 building is the largest airport terminal in the world. The massive complex is also the world’s largest building by floor space.

Extraordinary security and anti-narcotics measures are in place at DXB. Every foreigner who arrives here is subject to a retinal scan. U.A.E. applies the same policy to all airports in the country. There is also a very advanced drug detection system in place, capable of recognizing illegal substances in quantities as low as 0.001 grams.
